response.answer_text: You’ve really activated my trap card. I could talk about this all day. Better use of the thumbs Our thumbs are very strong and agile. It therefore seems a shame to relegate both to a single shared key, when our other fingers have the opportunity to use multiple keys. We should get rid of the giant shared space bar and ensure there are multiple keys for our thumbs to operate. Better ergonomics “Better ergonomics” is quite broad, so I’d focus on two areas. Firstly, if we separate the two halves of the keyboard, we can move them further away from each other to better accommodate our shoulders and wrists. The standard keyboard design forces us to “turn” (deviate) our wrists quite a lot, which is not comfortable in the long term; and it forces our hands close together, which in turn causes tension in our shoulders and necks. Secondly, our fingers are not great at side-to-side movement. There is no reason for the rows on a keyboard to be “staggered” like a typewriter keyboard. (This is a design holdover from typewriters that should have died out a long time ago, but such is the power of legacy.) Better key layout Some people believe that alphanumeric layouts like Dvorak or Colemak are inherently better. I don’t know whether this is true. What I do know is that the standard keyboard layout makes some very strange choices about which key to put where. For instance, Caps Lock is by definition not a key that you need to hold down to operate, whereas Ctrl is. So why is Ctrl placed in the furthest corners of the keyboard, where you have to stretch your pinky if you want to hold it down, while Caps Lock is placed in a close and convenient position? A common improvement that many power users make is to use software (or specialised hardware) to swap the positions of those two keys around. There are potentially many such changes we could make, such as putting held keys in the thumb position, where it’s very easy to hold them down while hitting other keys. Similarly, some keys could perform dual functions. Outside of gaming, a key like Ctrl is never tapped, only held. So we could easily make that key perform a different function, such as Esc, when we tap it without pressing anything else. This is another common hack that power users apply to get more functionality out of the same set of keys. Smaller layout Related to the above, the standard 104-key layout is too big. It requires hand movement, which is one of the biggest causes of poor keyboard efficiency, in order to access all functions. It is better to restrict the physical layout of the keyboard to a set of keys that can easily be reached, and find ways to map all desired functions to that set of keys. (As an aside: the standard keyboard layout also forces the mouse further to the right, outside of the optimal zone where you have maximal comfort and range of movement. Anyone who plays mouse-driven games seriously should use a smaller keyboard for their matches so that they can use the mouse more comfortably and effectively.) Some ways to map many functions to one key have already been discussed above. There are others, too. If you’ve used a laptop keyboard in the past ten years, you’ve probably had a Fn key that you could hold down to access additional functions on keys. This concept of “function layers” is very powerful, especially when you make the Fn key readily accessible & employ more than just one function layer. For example, you could let the Fn key access layer 1 when held, and toggle to layer 2 when tapped.  These are, as far as I’m concerned, the most important things we can and should improve with the standard keyboard. Luckily, specialist keyboards are available on the market today that have all of these features. I own an Ergodox EZ that has all of these features, and I couldn’t be happier. I only hope that mainstream manufacturers (especially laptop manufacturers) feel brave enough to take some risks & present the mass market with a better, more powerful, more comfortable tool.

The original question was “How can I play the keyboard.” Having clicked on “answer,” the question has been reworded as “How can I play good keyboard,” which is a different question. The facetious answer to the first question would be, “With your fingers.” The facetious answer to the second question would be, “Practice a lot.” But I presume you are asking a serious question and looking for a serious answer. Your question doesn't give any information about your present level, whether you already play at all, whether you can read music, whether you play other instruments, whether you are already a proficient keyboardist looking to get better. As a generalization, if you're starting out, I suggest you learn to play an acoustic piano first. You will learn much more about music and technique that way. It is easy to switch from acoustic piano to digital keyboard. Unfortunately, as many will tell you, it doesn't work so well the other way around. As far as using the capabilities of the digital keyboard, which is not my area, I think it depends partly on what kind of keyboard you have, whether you have been able to afford an expensive one, and exactly what you want to do with it musically. In any case, an experienced and qualified teacher here is a must.

Your teacher will probably guide you towards a suitable beginner book. Complete Keyboard Player has a set of 4 early learning books and then lots of other Songbooks, Pop, Jazz and Blues, movie Music, Disney Songs and many other categories, once you have some basic learning done. Pay attention to learning chords. If you have your left hand positioned so your little finger is on G and your thumb on D, you can reach all the notes you need to play all chords comfortably. Some, like G and A minor, will be in root position, but many chords will be in inversions. If you can learn them well, one or two at a time, or as those new chords appear in new music, your fingers will be able to find them quickly. Playing keyboard isn’t just about playing the right notes at the right times. It is about using all aspects of your instrument. So you will need to investigate the different voices and rhythms you can use, to make your music sound unique and interesting. And don’t forget the intros, fill-ins and endings too. The best way to learn keyboard is from a teacher that has mastered the instrument. He or she will give you structured lessons. That is what you need. Structured learning.

A one-on-one experience with a teacher can be a wonderful way to learn, however it can also be extremely expensive and time consuming. The other factor in dealing with a piano teacher is scheduling restraints. With the hustle and bustle life style today, who has time to drive to a trainer's house? Especially on the trainer's schedule! If you are serious and ready to learn there is a much more feasible solution! You can learn to play keyboard online and on your schedule! Learn to play keyboard with keyboard lessons online. Whether you are first starting out or already an intermediate keyboard player, you can learn to play with easy to use keyboard lessons online. Learning to play keyboard online allows you to learn when you have any amount of available time, not when you schedule it into your already hectic life. This method also allows you to work at your own pace and review lessons over and over again until you have full understanding of the concepts. Most online keyboard lessons are created by professional piano teachers and provide audio and visual aids to guide you through the learning process. There are also interactive programs to keep your attention and generate a "fun" environment to learn to play keyboard. Who ever said learning can't be fun!? Aside from the amount of time learning online will save you, and we all know time = money, online keyboard lessons can be obtained for much less than the cost of just 4 hours of time with a piano teacher! Don't waste any more time! You can start to learn to play keyboard today

The best way is what motivates you personally and feels most natural. Some people can self study quite successfully. Others need a bit of private music teaching. Others need a more structure from a wise mentor from start to finish. So there’s everything from online self study to short courses and video tutorials to private tutoring to long-term private lessons. I think one of the best ways to learn is finding a teacher that works well with you. I’ve heard horror stories from past piano students whose original piano teachers were not nurturing or conducive to piano progress. So I think it’s critical to find a teacher whose personality is a good match for your personality and learning style. Just like finding a good doctor, if you’re not satisfied— shop around. I have also written blogs on how to find a good piano teacher and what kind of keyboard is necessary if you’re interested in learning more: What Keyboard Do I Need For Successful Piano Lessons? The Scandinavians, and other Baltics, like the Poles, dropped the Q over a century back, as the letter is redundant, and has been for millennia, as say Quintilian noted, and the QI repeated: - "Q" is the least common letter in the English language, and there are arguments to suggest we do not need it at all. In 90AD, a Roman emperor stated that the letter "Q" was redundant except for the purpose of attaching vowels to itself. That emperor was called Quintilian. Languages that do not use the letter "Q" include Estonian, Icelandic, Latvian, Polish, Slovenian and Danish. Denmark abolished the use of the letter from native words in 1872. People often ask what is the best way to learn piano. I don’t think there is any particularly best way. It depends on how you learn best, and your own personal preferences. There are many ways to learn piano. These include: learning to play piano by earlearning to play piano with a personal tutorlearning to play piano in a group/classroom environmentbuying an online how to play piano course and learning on your ownFor some, the best way to learn piano is by ear. Some people find it very tedious to sit in a classroom environment. To them it’s pretty boring. The traditional ways of learning to play simply doesn’t appeal to them.
